subject: history
title: Major Acts & Legislation (1858-1885)
description: Comprehensive table of important acts, their provisions, and implications

rows.provisions: End of Company rule; Crown control; Secretary of State created; Viceroy appointed

details.description: Most important constitutional change in 19th century India
points: Secretary of State for India in British Cabinet
Council of India (15 members) to assist Secretary
Company's Court of Directors and Board of Control abolished
details.impact: India became direct colony of Britain; Company's commercial character ended

rows.provisions: Legislative councils expanded; some non-officials included; portfolio system introduced
rows.significance: Beginning of representative institutions in India

details.description: First step towards inclusion of Indians in legislation
points: Viceroy's Executive Council enlarged for legislation
Provincial legislative councils for Bengal, Bombay, Madras
Portfolio system: each executive council member given department
Power to make laws for peace and good government
Indians: Raja Dinkar Rao (Central Provinces), Raja of Benares
details.impact: Token representation but historic beginning; precedent set for Indian participation

rows.provisions: High Courts established at Calcutta, Bombay, Madras replacing Supreme Courts

points: Replaced Supreme Courts (Crown) and Sadar Courts (Company)
Indian judges also appointed alongside British
English as language of courts at higher levels
details.impact: Modern judicial system established; continues with modifications today

rows.provisions: Modern police force established; IG at state level; Superintendent at district level
rows.significance: Created police structure for law and order

points: Superintendent of Police (SP) at district level
British officers at top, Indians in lower ranks
Main purpose: protect British rule, suppress dissent
details.impact: Police system continues largely same; criticized for being repressive rather than service-oriented

rows.provisions: Codified criminal procedure law; investigation, trial, punishment procedures

points: Replaced varied systems of different presidencies
details.impact: Foundation of criminal justice administration in India

rows.provisions: Comprehensive criminal law code; defined offences and punishments

points: Drafted by first Law Commission under Macaulay (1834-1838)
Covered offenses against state, human body, property
Based on English law but adapted to Indian conditions
Replaced varied Muslim and Hindu laws partially
Age of consent for girls fixed at 10 (raised to 12 in 1891)
details.impact: Still in force with amendments; cornerstone of Indian criminal law
Foundation of modern currency and banking system

points: Also known as Civil Marriage Act
Couples could marry without religious ceremony
Mainly used by Brahmo Samaj members
Minimum age: 18 for boys, 14 for girls
details.impact: Legally broke caste/religious barriers; symbolically very important

rows.provisions: Forests declared government property; restrictions on access

points: Reserved forests: no access without permission
details.impact: Destroyed livelihood of tribals and forest dwellers; ecological damage

rows.provisions: Government could ban plays considered seditious

points: Bengali and Marathi theaters active in nationalist themes
Plays showing British in bad light banned
details.impact: Curtailed freedom of expression; showed British fear of cultural resistance

rows.provisions: Magistrate could demand security from vernacular newspapers; could ban without trial
rows.significance: Gagged Indian press; united Indian opinion against it

details.description: Most repressive press law in 19th century
points: Applied only to vernacular (Indian language) newspapers
details.impact: Backfired - united Indians; showed power of united protest; many papers switched to English to escape

rows.provisions: Indians required license to possess arms; Europeans exempt
rows.significance: Disarmed Indians; symbol of racial discrimination

points: Indians needed license to possess arms
After 1857, British didn't trust Indians with weapons
details.impact: Created resentment; symbol of British distrust and racial discrimination

rows.provisions: Strengthened 1865 Act; three categories of forests created

points: Three categories: Reserved, Protected, Village forests
Reserved: complete government control, no access
Village: nominal community control but govt supervision
details.impact: Systematic exploitation of forests; tribal rebellions followed in many areas

rows.provisions: First labor welfare legislation; limited child labor
rows.significance: Beginning of labor legislation in India

points: Applied to factories with 100+ workers using power
One day weekly off for children
Mainly in response to British factory owners' pressure
Indian mill owners wanted cheap child labor
details.impact: Token legislation; inadequate but historic beginning of labor welfare laws

rows.provisions: Increased government control over universities; Senate reduced; officials increased

points: Aimed at controlling educated middle class
Fear of educated Indians becoming revolutionary
details.impact: Centralized control; showed British fear of growing educated class; some improvement in standards

rows.provisions: Some protection to tenants against eviction

details.impact: Token reform; inadequate to solve agrarian distress

data.summary: The period saw important constitutional changes (end of Company rule, legislative councils), administrative reforms (police, judiciary), some social legislation (marriage, child labor), but also repressive laws (press, arms, forest acts). While some beneficial changes occurred, most legislation served British interests. Repressive laws united Indians in opposition and contributed to rise of nationalism.
